medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began approximately 2.5 weeks prior to admission with malaise, vomiting, and upper respiratory symptoms that resolved after 3 days. One week before admission, pruritus and dark urine developed, with darkening of skin attributed to sun exposure. Three days later, she took several medications for headache, then three days before admission, increasing discoloration of her eyes and skin led to an emergency department visit due to malaise, decreased appetite, and weight loss of approximately 3 kg over the previous month.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Three months earlier, the patient had given birth by spontaneous vaginal delivery after an uncomplicated pregnancy. There was an abnormal Papanicolaou smear for which colposcopy was planned. No history of blood transfusions or drug use. Prenatal tests for hepatitis B, C, and HIV were negative.
medical_history.family_history: Paternal grandmother had Laënnec’s cirrhosis, paternal grandfather had lung cancer, maternal relatives had type 2 diabetes mellitus and asthma; no other history of liver disease mentioned.
medical_history.social_history: The patient lives in a rural area with her child and boyfriend, stopped working early in her pregnancy, smokes cigarettes, drinks alcohol rarely, does not use intravenous drugs, and has no recent travel history outside New England.
